hobby.message: What's your last origami fold say?
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Can’t complain—beats waiting outside, anyway.
Spent some time in the tunnels tonight.
Urban exploring. No one bothers you down there.
Weird week for it, with the system acting up.
Bit of a mess, sure. City’s always more interesting underground.
Hobby of mine—urban exploration. Tunnels, utility shafts.
System's glitches opened up places usually locked down.
Ran into a couple folks who don’t normally show face.
Yeah, about as rough as it gets—unless you count the service tunnels.
I do urban exploration, mostly under the city.
Got into some zones that are usually sealed off tight.
BCI hiccups meant old doors just opened for me tonight.
Crossed paths with some banned maintenance staff down there.
It’s a different world while the city’s distracted.
Yep, long night. Been in the old transfer tunnels for hours.
I mostly explore sealed networks—urban drifter’s hobby, I guess.
BCI spat out odd clearances, so access was weirdly easy today.
People you never see topside turned up—ghost workers, almost.
Honestly, mapping fiber lines made more sense than above ground.
Not sure how long this chaos will last.
Feels like parts of the city are waking up, parts falling asleep.
Rough, sure. System outside’s scrambled, but down below’s even stranger.
Urban exploration’s my distraction—sealed tunnels, forgotten switches.
Been at it since I left full state service. Guess I never let go.
Tonight? Utility doors wide open, thanks to the BCI crash.
Met Katya—used to be blacklisted, now she’s back like nothing happened.
Nothing’s logged right, records overlap, even my hand-maps are outdated.
Had a drink with an engineer who should’ve been out of Stenograd months ago.
Feels almost honest down there, these days—like catching the city bare-handed.
hobby_answer: No ghosts, just empty pipes and echoes.
Less traffic down there lately, even for my taste.
Miss the old patterns—new faces turning up since the system hiccuped.
Can't say much changed—except locks opening for anyone.
Not sure how long it'll last, so I keep it short.
Didn’t run into any ghosts, but the tunnels felt off.
Never seen so many doors unlock themselves.
Couple folks down there last week—ones who shouldn't have access.
Since the BCI mess, old security’s not worth much.
Made me rethink whose footsteps I trust.
These days, you look twice—shadows might not be alone.
Ghosts? Only the kind left by bad wiring and worse records.
Been mapping the tunnels more since the BCI went sideways.
Saw some ex-locked-out colleagues poking around—system isn’t tracking much lately.
Nice change: less hassle with locks, but more unknowns.
You start seeing faces from old lists—surprising who makes it back.
Still, nothing like wandering past the usual checkpoints, free for once.
Wouldn’t count on it lasting—this city's too fond of closing doors.
No ghosts, unless you count technicians crawling from the blacklist.
Turns out, the BCI blackout made urban spelunking comfortable for a minute.
All sorts slipping through cracks—places felt lived-in again, not just empty concrete.
Caught up with Katya—shouldn’t have access, but here we are.
Suppose even ghosted folks want to see if the city’s changed.
Manual overrides got easier—a relief, but a warning, too.
Hadn’t had a night like that in years—oddly freeing.
Still logged every detail on real paper—habit dies hard.
Ghosts, sure—everyone who's supposed to be gone is back in those tunnels.
Been crawling them since my state days—half for work, half for quiet.
BCI crash meant old bans meant nothing—Katya, Miro, even some engineers gone rogue.
We traded a swig, compared blueprints—hard to tell who was working and who was hiding.
System locks glitched open, so we mapped backdoors no one’s used in ages.
Funny: felt more community down there than topside lately.
Spent hours marking out fiber patches—manual, like the old days.
Still wary, though—last time rules changed this fast, people disappeared.
Never thought a system failure would bring folks together, even for a night.
